TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . She was represented before the Court by Ms F. ORG , a member of ORG .

At the material time , the applicant was an associate professor at ORG . She began her career in DATE and said that she had worn the NORP headscarf when she obtained her doctorate in DATE and professorship in DATE .

In DATE she was the subject of a disciplinary investigation following an allegation that she had failed to comply with the rules on dress for public servants . On DATE she was suspended from her duties pending the outcome of the investigation . On DATE , pursuant to paragraphs CARDINAL ( g ) and CARDINAL ( m ) of LAW in ORG ( ORG , PERSON ve GPE Disiplin Yönetmeliği – “ the Disciplinary Procedure Rules ” ) , she was given a warning and declared ineligible for promotion for DATE on the ground that she had wilfully and persistently failed to comply with the applicable rules , despite receiving verbal and written reminders .

On DATE the applicant was reprimanded for continuing to wear the NORP headscarf while teaching . Finally , on CARDINAL DATE she was deemed to have resigned from her post under paragraph CARDINAL of the Disciplinary Procedure Rules , again on the ground that she had wilfully failed to comply with the Rules on Dress applicable to Staff in State Institutions ( PERSON ve kuruluşlarında çalışan personelin kılık - kıyafet yönetmeliği – “ the Rules on Dress ” ) .

On DATE she applied for an order setting aside the decision of CARDINAL May. She submitted , inter alia , that there was no statutory basis for the measure and that the relevant rules of procedure had not been followed .

On DATE a public hearing was held , which the applicant ’s counsel attended . On DATE , after deliberations , ORG rejected the applicant ’s application on the ground that the evidence in the investigation file showed that she had wilfully and persistently refused to comply with the rules on dress for public servants , despite being sent numerous reminders . It further found that the decision had been taken in accordance with the relevant procedural rules .

On DATE the applicant appealed on points of law against the judgment of DATE . She explained that , although paragraph CARDINAL ( a ) of the Rules on Dress prohibited female members of staff from wearing the headscarf when performing their duties in educational institutions , the penalty prescribed by paragraph CARDINAL ( g ) of the Disciplinary Procedure Rules for breaches of the Rules on Dress was a warning . Consequently , she argued that the only penalty to which she should have been liable was a warning or a reprimand and that the penalty imposed on her was unduly harsh and incompatible with the rights and freedoms protected by LAW .

On DATE Law no . CARDINAL came into force . It provided for public servants to be given an amnesty in respect of penalties imposed for disciplinary offences and for any resulting disability to be annulled .

In a judgment of DATE , ORG ruled on the basis of PERSON no . CARDINAL that it was unnecessary to examine the merits of the applicant ’s appeal on points of law since she had received an amnesty in respect of the penalties that had been imposed on her and the resulting disabilities had been annulled .

However , on DATE the applicant exercised her right under PERSON no . CARDINAL to lodge an application for orders reviving the proceedings and setting aside the judgment of DATE . She also requested a hearing .
In a judgment of DATE , ORG upheld the judgment of DATE without holding a hearing .

The ORG does not have any precise information on developments since the disciplinary penalties imposed on the applicant were cancelled , thereby giving her an opportunity to request reinstatement . However , the material before it indicates that the applicant , who argues that she has not received any written notification from the ORG , has not , in fact , requested reinstatement .

Provisional LAW no . CARDINAL on ORG employees ( PERSON ) of DATE , which was published in ORG of DATE , requires public servants to comply with rules on dress laid down by statute , circulars or regulations . LAW provides that a failure by a public servant to comply with the rules will result in a warning and , in the event of a repeated breach , the “ maximum penalty ” .

The Rules on Dress applicable to Staff in State Institutions ( PERSON ve kuruluşlarında çalışan personelin kılık - kıyafet yönetmeliği ) were adopted on CARDINAL DATE and published in ORG of DATE . At the material time , paragraph CARDINAL provided :
“ Female members of staff

Clothes shall be clean , proper , ironed and plain . Shoes shall be plain , low - heeled and polished . No head covering shall be worn on work premises ; hair shall be properly brushed and gathered , and nails cut . Trousers , blouses , and sleeveless or open - necked suits are prohibited . Skirts shall not be split or less than knee - length . Open shoes ( sandals ) shall not be worn .
Male members of staff

Clothes shall be clean , proper , ironed and plain . Shoes shall be plain and polished ... No head covering shall be worn on work premises ... Male members of staff shall not wear a beard and must shave DATE ... Ties shall be obligatory . ”

Paragraph CARDINAL of the Disciplinary Procedure Rules for Public Servants and Administrators in ORG sets out a list of the disciplinary penalties , namely a warning , a reprimand , suspension from administrative duties , loss of salary , ineligibility for promotion , deemed resignation and dismissal from office . Paragraph CARDINAL ( g ) lays down that the penalty for failing to comply with the Rules on Dress shall be a warning and , in the event of a repeated breach , the “ maximum penalty ” .

The Amnesty for Public Servants and State Employees ( Disciplinary Penalties ) Act ( Law no . CARDINAL ) came into force on DATE . Section CARDINAL provided , inter alia , that persons on whom disciplinary penalties had been imposed before DATE would receive an amnesty and that the penalty would be expunged from their service record . LAW entitled those concerned to make an application within DATE after DATE the LAW came into force for an order reviving the proceedings .
Transitional section CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL of DATE provides :
“ Choice of dress shall be free in institutions of higher education , provided that it does not contravene the law . ”
